metadata.title: Atlantic & Americas Shipwreck Database
metadata.description: Historic shipwrecks from Maine to Tierra del Fuego, including Caribbean, Gulf of Mexico, and Pacific South America. Focus on treasure ships with coins, jewels, and precious metals. Includes pre-1800 trade routes, pirate havens, colonial mining sites, mints, land routes, and mystery finds.
metadata.coverage: US East Coast, Gulf of Mexico, Caribbean, Central America, South America (Peru to Tierra del Fuego), Atlantic Ocean, Indian Ocean routes, Pacific Manila Galleon route
metadata.notes: Version 4.0: Restored 75+ wrecks. Added mining_sites, mints, land_routes, mystery_finds sections. Full Spanish colonial treasure ecosystem mapping.
metadata.location_notes: location_uncertainty_km indicates search radius for approximate positions. Null or 0 = precise location known.

John S. Potter Jr. - The Treasure Diver's Guide (1960, revised 1972)
Robert Sténuit - Treasures of the Armada (1972)
Eugene Lyon - The Search for the Atocha (1979)
Mendel Peterson - History Under the Sea (1969)
Pablo Pérez-Mallaína - Spain's Men of the Sea (1998)
Carla Rahn Phillips - Six Galleons for the King of Spain (1986)
William Lytle Schurz - The Manila Galleon (1939)
C.R. Boxer - The Portuguese Seaborne Empire 1415-1825 (1969)

Arquivo Nacional da Torre do Tombo (Lisbon)

Huguette & Pierre Chaunu - Séville et l'Amérique (1977)

trade_routes.description: Major treasure and trade routes before 1800. Waypoints include coordinates for mapping. Routes are arrays of waypoints in sailing order.

routes.name: Flota de Nueva España - Outbound (Spain to Mexico)
routes.description: The New Spain Fleet (Flota) departed Seville/Cádiz annually, sailing to Veracruz, Mexico to collect silver from Mexican mines and goods from the Manila Galleon trade.
routes.seasonal_notes: Departed Spain April-June to arrive before hurricane season. Mercury from Almadén mines was critical for silver amalgamation process.

waypoints.name: Seville (Departure before 1680)
waypoints.notes: Primary departure port until 1680. Ships loaded at Seville, sailed down Guadalquivir to Sanlúcar de Barrameda bar.

waypoints.name: Sanlúcar de Barrameda
waypoints.notes: Mouth of Guadalquivir. Treacherous bar crossing required pilots.

waypoints.name: Cádiz (Primary port after 1680)
waypoints.notes: Became primary departure port after 1680 due to silting of Guadalquivir.

waypoints.name: Canary Islands (Grand Canary/Tenerife)
waypoints.notes: Traditional provisioning stop. Last European port. Added wine, water, fresh provisions.

waypoints.name: Trade Wind Crossing Point
waypoints.notes: Picked up northeast trade winds for Atlantic crossing. ~3 weeks to Caribbean.

waypoints.name: Dominica/Guadeloupe Landfall
waypoints.notes: Typical Caribbean landfall. Lesser Antilles watering stop.

waypoints.name: San Juan, Puerto Rico
waypoints.notes: Often stopped for provisions and repairs. Royal situado payments delivered.

waypoints.name: Santo Domingo (optional)
waypoints.notes: Sometimes visited for official business.

waypoints.name: Veracruz, Mexico (Terminus)
waypoints.notes: Final destination. San Juan de Ulúa fortress. Silver from Mexico City mints and Manila Galleon goods loaded here.

routes.name: Flota de Nueva España - Return (Mexico to Spain)
routes.frequency: Annual (departed July-August, ideally before hurricane season peak)
routes.description: Return voyage carried Mexican silver and Asian luxury goods. Met Tierra Firme fleet at Havana for joint convoy to Spain.
routes.seasonal_notes: CRITICAL: Had to depart Veracruz by mid-August to avoid peak hurricane season (August-October). Many losses occurred when fleets delayed.

waypoints.name: Veracruz, Mexico (Departure)
waypoints.notes: Departed carrying silver and Asian goods from Manila trade.

waypoints.name: Yucatan Channel
waypoints.notes: Between Yucatan and Cuba. Swift currents, tricky navigation.

waypoints.name: Havana, Cuba (Rendezvous)
waypoints.notes: CRITICAL WAYPOINT. Met Tierra Firme fleet here. Combined fleets for safer Atlantic crossing. Careened and provisioned. Sometimes waited weeks for other fleet.

waypoints.name: Florida Straits
waypoints.notes: Gulf Stream current aided northward progress. MAJOR DANGER ZONE - hurricanes, reefs, shallow waters. Most 1715 and 1733 fleet losses here.

waypoints.name: Cape Hatteras (avoid)
waypoints.notes: Stayed well offshore to avoid 'Graveyard of the Atlantic'.

waypoints.name: Bermuda (emergency only)
waypoints.notes: Avoided if possible due to reefs. Emergency refuge only.

waypoints.name: Mid-Atlantic Westerlies
waypoints.notes: Picked up westerly winds for eastward crossing.

waypoints.name: Azores (Flores/Terceira)
waypoints.notes: Key waypoint. Provisioning, repairs. Could ride out storms. Last stop before Spain.

waypoints.name: Cape St. Vincent
waypoints.notes: SW tip of Portugal. Turn point toward Cádiz. Pirate/privateer hunting ground.

waypoints.name: Cádiz/Seville (Terminus)
waypoints.notes: Arrival. Treasure unloaded under guard to Casa de Contratación.

dangers: Vigo Bay area (War of Spanish Succession)

routes.name: Galeones de Tierra Firme - Outbound (Spain to South America)
routes.description: The Tierra Firme Fleet (Galeones) served the South American trade, collecting Peruvian silver at Portobelo, Panama and Colombian gold/emeralds at Cartagena.
routes.seasonal_notes: Departed later than New Spain Fleet. Had to coordinate with Pacific silver shipments from Peru arriving at Panama.

waypoints.name: Seville/Cádiz (Departure)
waypoints.notes: Same departure as New Spain Fleet.

waypoints.name: Canary Islands
waypoints.notes: Provisioning stop.

waypoints.name: Atlantic Crossing (southern route)
waypoints.notes: Slightly more southerly crossing than New Spain Fleet.

waypoints.name: Dominica/Martinique Landfall
waypoints.notes: Caribbean landfall. Fresh water and provisions.

waypoints.name: Cartagena de Indias, Colombia
waypoints.notes: MAJOR PORT. Colombian gold and emeralds loaded. Fleet waited here for Peruvian silver to arrive at Portobelo.

waypoints.name: Portobelo, Panama (Terminus)
waypoints.notes: Famous 'Feria de Portobelo' - great trade fair. Peruvian silver crossed isthmus from Panama City. Incredibly unhealthy - yellow fever killed many.

dangers: Same Atlantic dangers as New Spain route

routes.name: Galeones de Tierra Firme - Return (South America to Spain)
routes.description: Return voyage with South American treasure. The PERU SILVER ROUTE was the most valuable: Potosí mines → mule trains to Arica → ships to Callao → ships to Panama City → mule trains across isthmus → Portobelo → Spain.
routes.seasonal_notes: Departed Portobelo/Cartagena by May to reach Havana in time for combined fleet departure.

waypoints.name: Portobelo, Panama (Departure)
waypoints.notes: After Feria concluded. Silver loaded from Pacific side.

waypoints.name: Cartagena de Indias
waypoints.notes: Picked up Colombian treasure and additional ships.

waypoints.name: Havana, Cuba (Rendezvous)
waypoints.notes: Met New Spain Fleet. Combined for Atlantic crossing.

waypoints.name: Florida Straits → Azores → Spain
waypoints.notes: Same return route as New Spain Fleet after Havana.

peru_silver_sub_route.description: The feeder route that brought Peruvian silver to Portobelo

waypoints.name: Potosí Mines, Bolivia
waypoints.notes: Source of most Spanish colonial silver. 'Cerro Rico' (Rich Hill). Elevation 13,420 ft.

waypoints.name: Arica, Peru (now Chile)
waypoints.notes: Pacific port. Silver arrived by llama/mule train from Potosí.

waypoints.name: Callao, Peru
waypoints.notes: Port of Lima. Silver consolidated here. Royal mint. Armada del Mar del Sur (South Sea Fleet) based here.

waypoints.name: Panama City, Panama
waypoints.notes: Pacific terminus. Silver unloaded for overland crossing.

waypoints.name: Cruces/Venta de Cruces
waypoints.notes: Inland town. Mule trains crossed isthmus on 'Camino Real' (royal road) or river route via Chagres.

waypoints.name: Portobelo, Panama
waypoints.notes: Caribbean terminus. Silver loaded onto Tierra Firme Fleet.

notable_disasters: 1622 (Atocha lost waiting for late Tierra Firme silver)

routes.name: Carreira da Índia - Outbound (Lisbon to India)
routes.description: The Portuguese 'India Run' was the longest regular trade route of the age of sail. Ships sailed from Lisbon around Africa to Goa, with voyages often continuing to Malacca, Macau, and Japan.
routes.seasonal_notes: CRITICAL: Had to depart Lisbon by April to catch SW monsoon arriving India by September. Late departure meant missing monsoon = waiting a year in Mozambique.

waypoints.name: Lisbon, Portugal (Departure)
waypoints.notes: Belém Tower departure point. Ships blessed at Jerónimos Monastery.

waypoints.name: Madeira (optional)
waypoints.notes: Sometimes stopped for wine and provisions.

waypoints.name: Canary Islands (avoided)
waypoints.notes: Spanish territory - Portuguese avoided.

waypoints.name: Cape Verde Islands
waypoints.notes: Portuguese provisioning stop. Santiago Island main port.

waypoints.name: Equatorial Doldrums
waypoints.notes: Windless zone. Could take weeks to cross. Water and food spoilage critical.

waypoints.name: Brazilian Coast Approach
waypoints.notes: Sailed west toward Brazil to catch favorable currents and winds.

waypoints.name: Cape of Good Hope
waypoints.notes: 'Cape of Storms'. Most dangerous part of voyage. Extreme winds, waves. Many ships lost here.

waypoints.name: Mozambique Channel
waypoints.notes: Between Madagascar and Africa. Provisioning at Mozambique Island.

waypoints.name: Mozambique Island
waypoints.notes: Portuguese base. Hospital, provisions. Ships wintered here if they missed monsoon.

waypoints.name: Arabian Sea Crossing
waypoints.notes: Rode SW monsoon (June-September) across to India.

waypoints.name: Goa, India (Terminus)
waypoints.notes: Portuguese India capital. Primary terminus. Ships could continue to Malacca, Macau, Nagasaki.

to_malacca.notes: Spice trade center. Cloves, nutmeg, mace.

to_nagasaki.notes: Japan trade (until 1639 expulsion). Silver exchanged for silk.

routes.name: Carreira da Índia - Return (India to Lisbon)
routes.description: Return voyage with Asian luxury goods. Required precise timing with monsoons. One of the most valuable cargoes of any trade route.
routes.seasonal_notes: CRITICAL: Depart Goa December-January to catch NE monsoon. Round Cape before winter (June-August = southern winter = worst storms).

waypoints.name: Goa, India (Departure)
waypoints.notes: Departed December-January on NE monsoon.

waypoints.name: Mozambique Channel
waypoints.notes: Stopped at Mozambique Island for provisions.

waypoints.name: Cape of Good Hope
waypoints.notes: Rounded Cape March-May before southern winter.

waypoints.name: St. Helena Island (after 1502)
waypoints.notes: Portuguese discovered 1502. Provisioning stop on return only (not outbound due to winds). Fresh water, meat, fruit.

waypoints.name: Azores (Terceira)
waypoints.notes: Final provisioning before Portugal. Portuguese territory.

waypoints.name: Lisbon (Terminus)
waypoints.notes: Arrival. Cargo unloaded at Casa da Índia.

routes.name: Manila Galleon - Westbound (Acapulco to Manila)
routes.description: The 'Nao de China' or Manila Galleon linked Spanish America to Asia. Mexican silver (the world's trade currency) was exchanged for Chinese silk, porcelain, and spices.
routes.seasonal_notes: Departed Acapulco March-April to reach Manila before SW monsoon ended.

waypoints.name: Acapulco, Mexico (Departure)
waypoints.notes: Only authorized Pacific port. Annual fair when galleon arrived. Silver loaded.

waypoints.name: North Equatorial Current
waypoints.notes: Rode current westward. Relatively easy passage.

waypoints.name: Guam/Mariana Islands
waypoints.notes: Spanish territory. Provisioning stop. Fresh water critical.

waypoints.name: San Bernardino Strait
waypoints.notes: Entrance to Philippine archipelago.

waypoints.name: Manila, Philippines (Terminus)
waypoints.notes: Spanish colonial capital. Chinese merchants brought goods to Parián market.

routes.name: Manila Galleon - Eastbound (Manila to Acapulco) - THE TORNAVIAJE
routes.description: The TORNAVIAJE (return voyage) was one of the most grueling regular voyages in maritime history. Ships sailed far north to catch westerly winds, then south along the California coast. 4-6 months at sea.
routes.seasonal_notes: Departed Manila July-August to catch SW monsoon north. Had to reach California before winter storms.

waypoints.name: Manila, Philippines (Departure)
waypoints.notes: Departed July-August on SW monsoon.

waypoints.name: San Bernardino Strait
waypoints.notes: Exit to Pacific.

waypoints.name: North into Kuroshio Current
waypoints.notes: Sailed north to pick up Japan Current (Kuroshio).

waypoints.name: North Pacific High Point
waypoints.notes: Reached as far north as 38-42°N. Cold, stormy, scurvy-ridden.

waypoints.name: Westerly Wind Belt
waypoints.notes: Rode westerlies across vast Pacific. Could be becalmed for weeks.

waypoints.name: Cape Mendocino (California Landfall)
waypoints.notes: First North American landfall. Great relief. Then coast south.

waypoints.name: Monterey Bay (after 1602)
waypoints.notes: Authorized stop (after 1602 for provisions, though rarely used).

waypoints.name: California Coast Sailing
waypoints.notes: Sailed south along coast. Crews often too weak from scurvy to work ship.

waypoints.name: Cape San Lucas
waypoints.notes: Tip of Baja California. Turn toward Acapulco.

waypoints.name: Acapulco, Mexico (Terminus)
waypoints.notes: Arrival triggered great fair. Silk sold for silver.

dangers: Ship structural failure from long voyage

routes.name: Dutch VOC Route - Outbound (Amsterdam to Batavia)
routes.description: The VOC (Verenigde Oostindische Compagnie) developed the fastest route to Asia by using the 'Roaring Forties' - powerful westerly winds in the southern latitudes.
routes.seasonal_notes: Departed Europe May-September. Timed to reach Cape before southern winter, then ride Roaring Forties.

waypoints.name: Texel/Amsterdam (Departure)
waypoints.notes: VOC headquarters. Ships assembled at Texel roadstead.

waypoints.name: English Channel
waypoints.notes: Dangerous passage. Risk of war with England.

waypoints.name: Cape Verde Islands (avoided)
waypoints.notes: Portuguese territory - VOC avoided, sailed direct.

waypoints.name: South Atlantic
waypoints.notes: Direct sail to Cape, avoiding African coast.

waypoints.name: Cape of Good Hope
waypoints.notes: Dutch established colony 1652. Table Bay anchorage. Provisioning, repairs.

waypoints.name: Roaring Forties Entry
waypoints.notes: INNOVATION: Sailed east into Roaring Forties rather than up African coast.

waypoints.name: Roaring Forties Crossing
waypoints.notes: Powerful westerlies pushed ships rapidly east. Cold, dangerous, but fast.

waypoints.name: Turn North Point
waypoints.notes: Turned north toward Sunda Strait. If missed turn, wrecked on Australia (many did).

waypoints.name: Sunda Strait
waypoints.notes: Between Java and Sumatra. Entrance to Indonesian archipelago.

waypoints.name: Batavia (Jakarta), Java (Terminus)
waypoints.notes: VOC Asian headquarters. Massive warehouses, shipyards, hospital.

routes.name: Dutch VOC Route - Return (Batavia to Amsterdam)
routes.description: Return voyage followed reverse route, but timing critical to avoid Cape winter storms.
routes.seasonal_notes: Departed Batavia October-January. Had to round Cape before June (southern winter).

waypoints.name: Batavia, Java (Departure)
waypoints.notes: Departed October-January with monsoon.

waypoints.name: Sunda Strait
waypoints.notes: Exit to Indian Ocean.

waypoints.name: Indian Ocean Crossing
waypoints.notes: Direct route to Cape.

waypoints.name: Cape of Good Hope
waypoints.notes: Provisioning. Departed before winter.

waypoints.name: St. Helena Island
waypoints.notes: English after 1659, but often used by VOC. Provisioning.

waypoints.name: Ascension Island (optional)
waypoints.notes: Emergency provisioning only.

waypoints.name: Azores (avoided)
waypoints.notes: Portuguese territory.

waypoints.name: English Channel
waypoints.notes: Home stretch. Privateers and navy threats.

waypoints.name: Texel/Amsterdam (Terminus)
waypoints.notes: Arrival. Cargo auctioned by VOC.

routes.name: Atlantic Triangle Trade
routes.description: The infamous triangular trade: European goods to Africa, slaves to Americas, colonial products to Europe. Multiple variants existed.

route.name: West African Coast
route.notes: Gold Coast, Slave Coast, Bight of Benin.

route.name: West African Ports
route.notes: Ouidah, Elmina, Calabar, Bonny, Luanda, etc.

route.name: Mid-Atlantic Crossing
route.notes: 'Middle Passage'. Horrific mortality. 10-15% average death rate.

route.name: Caribbean/Americas Arrival
route.notes: Jamaica, Barbados, Cuba, Brazil, US South.

mining_sites.description: Colonial-era mining sites that produced the treasure found on shipwrecks. Source of wealth for Spanish and Portuguese empires.

sites.name: Potosí (Cerro Rico)
sites.peak_output: Produced 60% of world's silver at peak. ~41,000 tons total 1556-1783.
sites.description: The 'Rich Mountain' - largest silver deposit ever found. Funded Spanish Empire for 200 years. Mita labor system killed estimated 8 million indigenous workers. Silver coins minted on-site from 1572.
sites.notes: UNESCO World Heritage Site. Still producing small amounts. City population reached 160,000 in 1650 (larger than London).
sources: Bakewell - Miners of the Red Mountain

sites.name: Huancavelica
sites.peak_output: Supplied mercury for all Peruvian and much Mexican silver refining
sites.description: Called 'Mine of Death' - mercury poisoning killed thousands. Mercury essential for silver amalgamation process (patio process). Connected to Potosí by mule train.
sites.notes: Mercury shipped to Potosí despite enormous distance because Mexican mercury from Almadén was even further. Mercury poisoning endemic.
sources: Lohmann Villena - Las minas de Huancavelica

sites.name: Porco
sites.description: Pre-Columbian silver mine expanded by Spanish. Produced significant silver before Potosí overshadowed it. Inca had mined here before conquest.
sites.notes: One of first Spanish silver mines in Peru. Quickly eclipsed by Potosí.
sources: Marx - Shipwrecks of the Western Hemisphere

sites.name: Oruro
sites.peak_output: Second largest Bolivian producer after Potosí
sites.description: Important secondary silver source. Also produced tin. Native uprising 1781. Became tin-mining center in 19th century.
sites.notes: UNESCO World Heritage for cultural traditions.
sources: Bakewell - Miners of the Red Mountain

sites.name: Zacatecas
sites.peak_output: Mexico's largest silver producer - ~20% of all Mexican silver
sites.description: First major Mexican silver strike. Built colonial wealth of New Spain. Silver road (Camino de la Plata) connected to Mexico City and Veracruz.
sites.notes: UNESCO World Heritage Site. Still active mining district.
sources: Bakewell - Silver Mining and Society in Colonial Mexico

sites.name: Guanajuato
sites.peak_output: By 1800, produced 25% of world's silver. La Valenciana mine world's richest.
sites.description: Second wave Mexican silver. La Valenciana mine reached 500m depth. Peak production during late colonial period. Site of independence movement start (1810).
sites.notes: UNESCO World Heritage Site. Underground streets.
sources: Brading - Miners and Merchants in Bourbon Mexico

sites.name: Taxco
sites.description: First significant Spanish silver mine in Mexico. José de la Borda revived mines in 18th century. Santa Prisca church built with silver profits.
sites.notes: Known for silver jewelry today. Closest major mine to Mexico City.
sources: West - The Mining Community in Northern New Spain

sites.name: Real del Monte (Mineral del Monte)
sites.peak_output: Major producer in late colonial period
sites.description: Near Pachuca. British Company of Adventurers invested heavily in 1820s. Cornish miners introduced pasty (now regional dish). Deep mines required drainage innovations.
sites.notes: Cornish miners left cultural legacy including football (soccer).
sources: Randall - Real del Monte: A British Mining Venture in Mexico

sites.name: Muzo
sites.peak_output: World's finest emeralds. Colombian emeralds 90% of world market.
sites.description: Legendary emerald mines. Muzo emeralds most valued for deep green color. Thousands died in brutal mining conditions. Spanish Crown monopoly.
sites.notes: Still producing. Muzo emeralds command highest prices. Color called 'Muzo green'.

sites.name: Buriticá
sites.peak_output: Major gold source for early colonial period
sites.description: Pre-Columbian gold mining area expanded by Spanish. Near Antioquia gold fields. Placer and lode mining.
sites.notes: Antioquia region remained Colombia's gold center.
sources: West - Colonial Placer Mining in Colombia

sites.name: Chocó
sites.peak_output: Colombia's richest gold region; only significant platinum source until 1800
sites.description: Pacific lowland placer mining. First platinum found (initially discarded as 'platina' - little silver). African slave labor. Extremely unhealthy tropical conditions.
sites.notes: Platinum considered worthless until 18th century scientific interest. Still gold panning today.
sources: Sharp - Slavery on the Spanish Frontier

sites.name: Almadén
sites.peak_output: World's largest mercury mine - supplied Mexican silver refining
sites.description: Critical to silver production. Mercury shipped to Veracruz for Mexican mines. Roman, Moorish, then Spanish exploitation. Brutal convict labor. UNESCO World Heritage.
sites.notes: Mercury essential for patio process silver extraction. Fugger banking family had lease 1525-1645.

mints.description: Colonial mints (Casas de Moneda) that produced the coins found in shipwrecks. Mint marks on coins help identify treasure origins.

mints.name: Casa de Moneda de México (Mexico City Mint)
mints.description: First mint in the Americas. Produced most Spanish colonial coinage. 'Pieces of Eight' (8 reales) became world trade currency. Largest mint in the world by 1700s.
mints.notes: Building still stands as Museum of the Cultures. Pillar dollars, then milled coinage from 1732.

mints.name: Casa de Moneda de Lima (Lima Mint)
mints.description: Second mint in Americas. Processed silver from Upper Peru (Bolivia). Intermittent operation - sometimes closed when Potosí mint active.
mints.notes: Competed with Potosí mint. Produced cobs and later milled coinage.

mints.name: Casa de Moneda de Potosí (Potosí Mint)
mints.description: Mint at the source - coins struck where silver was mined. Largest mint building in South America (current building from 1773). Produced vast majority of cob coinage.
mints.notes: Building is now museum. Most treasure fleet silver came from here. 'P' mint mark most common on colonial cobs.

mints.name: Casa de Moneda de Bogotá (Bogotá Mint)
mints.description: Minted Colombian gold and some silver. Important gold escudo production. Served New Granada viceroyalty.
mints.notes: Colombia was gold country - more gold coins than silver. Now Museo Casa de la Moneda.
sources: Restrepo - Monedas de la República de Colombia

mints.name: Casa de Moneda de Guatemala (Guatemala Mint)
mints.description: Served Central American silver production. Relatively late establishment. Moved from Antigua to Guatemala City after 1773 earthquake.
mints.notes: Smaller output than Mexican or Peruvian mints. Rare coins highly valued by collectors.

mints.name: Casa de Moneda de Chile (Santiago Mint)
mints.description: Late colonial mint. Produced gold and silver coins. Building designed by Italian architect Toesca, now La Moneda presidential palace.
mints.notes: La Moneda palace (site of 1973 coup) is former mint building.

land_routes.description: Overland treasure routes that connected mines to ports. Silver and gold traveled these trails before reaching the sea.

routes.name: Potosí to Arica Silver Road
routes.description: Primary route for Potosí silver to reach Pacific coast. Llama and mule trains crossed high Andes. 400km journey taking 15-20 days.

waypoints.name: Potosí
waypoints.notes: Departure - silver loaded from mint and refineries

waypoints.name: Puna de Atacama (High Plateau)
waypoints.notes: 4000m+ altitude crossing. Extreme cold and altitude sickness.

waypoints.name: Tacna area
waypoints.notes: Descent toward coast

waypoints.name: Arica
waypoints.notes: Pacific port. Silver loaded onto ships for Callao.

routes.transport: Llama trains (early), Mule trains (later). 1000+ animals per caravan.
routes.notes: This route made Arica wealthy. Mercury transported in reverse direction.
sources: Bakewell - Miners of the Red Mountain

routes.name: Potosí to Lima (via Arequipa)
routes.description: Alternative route via Arequipa for silver destined directly for Lima. Longer but lower altitude in places.

waypoints.name: Potosí
waypoints.notes: Departure

waypoints.name: Oruro
waypoints.notes: Secondary silver mining town

waypoints.name: Lake Titicaca region
waypoints.notes: High plateau, tambo inns

waypoints.name: Arequipa
waypoints.notes: Major colonial city, rest stop

waypoints.name: Lima
waypoints.notes: Viceregal capital, connection to Callao

routes.name: Huancavelica to Potosí Mercury Route
routes.description: Critical supply route. Mercury from Huancavelica essential for silver extraction at Potosí. 1500km journey.

waypoints.name: Huancavelica
waypoints.notes: Mercury mines - 'Mine of Death'

waypoints.name: Ayacucho
waypoints.notes: Colonial town, rest stop

waypoints.name: Cuzco
waypoints.notes: Former Inca capital, major waypoint

waypoints.name: Lake Titicaca region
waypoints.notes: High plateau crossing

waypoints.name: Potosí
waypoints.notes: Destination - mercury delivered to refineries

routes.transport: Mule trains. Mercury packed in leather bags inside wooden boxes.
routes.notes: Without this route, Potosí production would have collapsed. Mercury monopoly critical to Crown revenue.

routes.name: Callao to Panama City (Armada del Sur)
routes.description: Pacific leg of Peru silver route. Armada del Mar del Sur (South Sea Fleet) carried treasure from Callao to Panama for isthmus crossing.

waypoints.name: Callao
waypoints.notes: Port of Lima, departure point

waypoints.name: Paita
waypoints.notes: Northern Peru port, sometimes stopped

waypoints.name: Guayaquil
waypoints.notes: Ecuadorian port, shipbuilding center

waypoints.name: Panama City
waypoints.notes: Pacific terminus, unloading for isthmus crossing

routes.transport: Ships of Armada del Mar del Sur
routes.notes: This route made Pacific coast vulnerable - Drake captured Nuestra Señora de la Concepción (Cacafuego) 1579.
sources: Clayton - Pirates and the California Coast

routes.name: Panama Isthmus Crossing (Camino Real / Camino de Cruces)
cargo: All treasure from South America destined for Spain
routes.description: Critical chokepoint. All Peruvian silver crossed 80km of jungle between Panama City (Pacific) and Portobelo (Caribbean). Two routes: overland Camino Real or river via Chagres.

waypoints.name: Panama City
waypoints.notes: Pacific side terminus

waypoints.name: Cruces (for river route)
waypoints.notes: Transfer point to river boats

waypoints.name: Chagres River route
waypoints.notes: Canoe/barge down river in wet season

waypoints.name: Venta de Cruces (for land route)
waypoints.notes: Rest stop on Camino Real

waypoints.name: Portobelo
waypoints.notes: Caribbean terminus, treasure fairs, fleet loading

routes.transport: Mule trains (Camino Real - dry season) or river boats then mules (Camino de Cruces - wet season)
routes.notes: Panama Railroad (1855) finally replaced mule trains. Morgan used same route in reverse for Panama City raid 1671.

routes.name: Zacatecas to Veracruz (Camino de la Plata)
routes.description: Mexican Silver Road. Connected northern silver mines to Gulf coast port. Later extended to San Luis Potosí, Durango, and beyond.

waypoints.name: Zacatecas
waypoints.notes: Northern mining center

waypoints.name: San Luis Potosí
waypoints.notes: Mining and commerce center

waypoints.name: Querétaro
waypoints.notes: Major colonial city

waypoints.name: Mexico City
waypoints.notes: Capital, mint, silver consolidated

waypoints.name: Puebla
waypoints.notes: Colonial city

waypoints.name: Orizaba Pass
waypoints.notes: Descent through mountains

waypoints.name: Veracruz
waypoints.notes: Caribbean port, fleet loading

routes.notes: Fortified convoys needed due to bandits. Bajío region grew wealthy from trade.
sources: West - The Mining Community in Northern New Spain

routes.name: Acapulco to Veracruz (Trans-Mexico Route)
routes.description: Connected Pacific Manila Galleon trade to Atlantic treasure fleets. Asian goods landed at Acapulco, crossed Mexico, shipped to Spain from Veracruz.

waypoints.name: Acapulco
waypoints.notes: Pacific port, Manila Galleon terminus

waypoints.name: Chilpancingo
waypoints.notes: Mountain town

waypoints.name: Cuernavaca
waypoints.notes: Pleasant climate rest stop

waypoints.name: Mexico City
waypoints.notes: Capital, great fair, goods redistributed

waypoints.name: Puebla
waypoints.notes: Secondary market

waypoints.name: Veracruz
waypoints.notes: Atlantic port for goods going to Spain

routes.notes: Chinese silk became so popular in Spain that domestic silk industry protested. Trade restrictions imposed but widely evaded.

routes.name: Potosí to Buenos Aires (Contraband Route)
routes.description: Illegal route bypassing Lima and Spain's trade monopoly. Silver smuggled to Buenos Aires, traded with Portuguese and later British ships. Estimated 20-50% of Potosí silver left this way.

waypoints.name: Potosí
waypoints.notes: Source of contraband silver

waypoints.name: Sucre (La Plata/Chuquisaca)
waypoints.notes: Colonial capital of Upper Peru

waypoints.name: Tucumán
waypoints.notes: Trade hub, mule breeding

waypoints.name: Córdoba
waypoints.notes: Major colonial city

waypoints.name: Buenos Aires
waypoints.notes: Rio de la Plata port - contraband ships waited

routes.transport: Mule trains, ox carts across pampas
routes.notes: This route drained so much silver that Spain eventually legalized Buenos Aires trade (1778 free trade reforms). Portuguese in Colonia del Sacramento were main trading partners.
sources: Socolow - The Merchants of Buenos Aires

mystery_finds.description: Unexplained artifact discoveries, orphan finds not linked to known wrecks, and legendary lost ships. Potential future discovery sites.

finds.name: Jupiter Inlet Cannon Fields
finds.description: Cannons and anchors found not matching any documented wreck. Possible undiscovered 16th-17th century Spanish ship.
finds.notes: Florida coast has many undocumented losses. Not all AGI records survive.

finds.name: Melbourne Beach Coin Scatter
finds.description: Regular coin finds not attributable to 1715 fleet. Different dates and mints suggest separate wreck.
finds.notes: Could be extension of 1715 fleet debris or separate earlier loss.

finds.name: Beeswax Wreck (Santo Cristo de Burgos?)
finds.description: Manila Galleon wrecked on Oregon coast, possibly Santo Cristo de Burgos (1693). Beeswax blocks with Spanish markings wash up for centuries. Possible link to local Native American stories.
finds.potential_origin: Manila Galleon - Santo Cristo de Burgos 1693 or San Francisco Xavier 1705
finds.notes: Would be northernmost Manila Galleon wreck. Native oral histories describe 'Ship that came ashore'. Nehalem Bay area.

finds.name: Silver Shoals Extended Debris Field
finds.description: Areas around known Concepción (1641) wreck site showing artifacts potentially from other vessels. Multiple ships may have wrecked on these reefs.
finds.notes: Silver Shoals extremely dangerous - many ships wrecked here over centuries.

finds.name: Turks and Caicos Artifact Scatters
finds.description: Multiple finds of colonial-era artifacts on various islands not linked to documented wrecks. Area on major shipping routes.
finds.notes: Many reefs made this area ship graveyard. Salt trade, then treasure route.

finds.name: De Soto Canyon Artifact Area
finds.description: Oil/gas industry sonar has detected anomalies in De Soto Canyon area. Some may be historical wrecks.
finds.potential_origin: Unknown - possibly colonial Spanish, possibly later
finds.notes: Deep water (300-600m) makes investigation difficult. May include 1559 Luna fleet vessels.

finds.name: Lost Ship of the Desert
finds.description: Legendary Spanish ship said to be buried in Colorado Desert / Salton Sink area of California. Multiple reported sightings over centuries.
finds.potential_origin: Possibly Manila Galleon exploring Gulf of California, or pearl fishing vessel
finds.notes: Could relate to 1612 Nicolás Cardona expedition or earlier exploration. Ancient Lake Cahuilla did connect to Gulf of California. Probably myth, but Gulf exploration did occur.
sources: Pepper - The Lost Ship of the Desert

finds.name: Frying Pan Shoals Colonial Artifacts
finds.description: Dangerous shoals off Cape Fear, NC with artifacts suggesting colonial-era wrecks not fully documented.
finds.notes: Major shipping hazard - many undocumented losses likely.

finds.name: Point Reyes Manila Galleon Site Extensions
finds.description: Beyond known San Agustín (1595) site, artifacts suggest larger debris field or possibly second vessel.
finds.potential_origin: San Agustín debris field or unknown second vessel
finds.notes: San Agustín carried full Manila Galleon cargo - extensive debris expected.

finds.name: Florida Keys Unidentified Ballast Piles
finds.description: Numerous ballast piles in Keys not attributed to 1622, 1715, or 1733 fleets. Colonial ships that never made records.
finds.status: Various - some protected, some actively worked
finds.notes: Keys saw centuries of traffic. Many small vessels never documented.

finds.name: Trinidad/Tobago Colonial Artifact Reports
finds.description: Fishermen reports and occasional finds of colonial-era materials. Area was off main routes but ships did pass through.
finds.notes: Lesser Antilles generally less explored than Greater Antilles.

finds.name: Chiloé Island Galleon Legends
finds.description: Local legends of Spanish galleon wrecked on Chiloé archipelago, Chile. Area was on Pacific route.
finds.potential_origin: Possibly Pacific supply ship or storm-driven treasure ship
finds.notes: Chile's southern coast extremely hazardous. Many colonial ships lost without records.

finds.name: Bahia (Salvador) Offshore Anomalies
finds.description: Sonar surveys off Brazil's historic colonial capital have identified targets consistent with colonial-era ships.
finds.potential_origin: Portuguese India fleet vessels, sugar ships, or others
finds.status: Brazilian government jurisdiction - limited private exploration
finds.notes: Salvador was major port for sugar trade and Portuguese India fleet stops.

pirate_havens.description: Known pirate bases, hideouts, and safe harbors during the Golden Age of Piracy (1650-1730) and earlier/later periods.

havens.name: Port Royal, Jamaica
havens.description: Called 'the wickedest city on Earth'. English buccaneers operated from here with government approval during wars with Spain. Henry Morgan's base. Destroyed by earthquake 1692.
havens.destroyed: 1692 earthquake (2/3 of city sank into sea)

havens.name: Nassau, New Providence, Bahamas
havens.description: The 'Republic of Pirates'. Self-governing pirate community after 1715 fleet disaster provided easy pickings. Ended when Woodes Rogers arrived as governor 1718 with pardons and hangings.

havens.name: Tortuga (Île de la Tortue), Haiti
havens.description: Original buccaneer stronghold. Name means 'Turtle Island'. French buccaneers hunted wild cattle on Hispaniola, turned to piracy. Fortified harbor.

havens.name: Île Sainte-Marie (Nosy Boraha), Madagascar
havens.description: Premier Indian Ocean pirate base. 'Pirate Utopia' myths. Strategic for Red Sea/India raids. Adam Baldridge established trading post 1691. Pirate graveyard still exists.
havens.features: Protected harbor, friendly natives, careening beaches, fresh provisions

havens.name: Barataria Bay, Louisiana
havens.description: Jean Lafitte's smuggling empire. Not classic 'pirates' - primarily smuggled goods (including slaves) past US customs. Fought with Americans at Battle of New Orleans 1815.
havens.features: Maze of bayous, impossible to patrol

havens.name: Ocracoke Inlet, North Carolina
havens.description: Blackbeard's favorite hiding spot. Shallow waters kept navy ships away. Site of his death November 22, 1718.
havens.features: Shallow inlet, many channels, hard to navigate for outsiders

havens.name: Libertatia (Libertalia) - LIKELY FICTIONAL
havens.description: PROBABLY FICTIONAL. Legendary pirate utopia supposedly founded by Captain Misson and Defrocked priest Caraccioli in northern Madagascar. Described in Charles Johnson's 'General History of the Pyrates' (1724). No archaeological or contemporary documentary evidence.
havens.historicity: No contemporary evidence. Likely invented by Johnson/Defoe.
sources: Johnson - General History of the Pyrates (1724)

havens.name: Petit-Goâve, Saint-Domingue (Haiti)
havens.description: French buccaneer capital of Saint-Domingue. Governor de Pouançay and de Cussy issued privateering commissions freely. Major raid staging point.

havens.name: St. Thomas, Danish West Indies (Virgin Islands)
havens.description: Danish neutrality made it a 'no questions asked' port. Pirates sold plunder here openly. Governor Adolph Esmit was notoriously corrupt, sheltered pirates.
notable_pirates: Various - served as fence for stolen goods
havens.features: Neutral port, corrupt officials, good market for plunder

havens.name: Galveston Island, Texas
havens.description: Jean Lafitte's base after leaving Barataria. 'Campeche' colony. Operated under Mexican rebel privateer commissions against Spain. Burned and abandoned 1821 after attacking US ship.

havens.name: Ranter Bay (St. Augustine Bay), Madagascar
havens.description: Southwest Madagascar. Pirates renamed it 'Ranter Bay'. Good for careening (cleaning ship bottoms). Less famous than Île Sainte-Marie but regularly used.
havens.features: Protected bay, careening beach, native trade

havens.name: Johanna (Anjouan), Comoros Islands
havens.description: Indian Ocean provisioning stop. Sultan welcomed trade with all comers including pirates. Fresh water, meat, fruit available.
notable_pirates: Henry Every provisioned here 1695 after Mughal raid
havens.features: Friendly native ruler, fresh provisions, central location

havens.name: Cartagena (Pirate attacks)
havens.description: NOT a pirate haven - a major TARGET. Sacked by Francis Drake 1586, by Baron de Pointis and Du Casse 1697. One of the most heavily fortified ports in the Americas.
havens.current_status: Colombian city. UNESCO World Heritage fortifications.

havens.name: Salé (Sallee), Morocco
havens.description: The 'Sallee Rovers' or 'Sallee Pirates'. Barbary corsairs who operated independently of Ottoman control. Raided as far as Iceland, Ireland, England. Sold European captives as slaves.
havens.features: River mouth port, hard to attack

havens.name: Algiers, Algeria
havens.description: Primary Barbary corsair port. Nominally Ottoman but effectively independent. Massive slave market for European captives. Regular target of European punitive expeditions.
havens.features: Fortified harbor, Ottoman naval support, slave markets

havens.name: Tunis, Tunisia
havens.description: Second major Barbary corsair port after Algiers. Also participated in Mediterranean and Atlantic raiding.

havens.name: Tripoli, Libya
havens.description: Third major Barbary corsair base. Target of US Navy in First Barbary War (1801-1805) - 'shores of Tripoli' in Marine Corps Hymn.

havens.name: Dunkirk, France
havens.description: Spanish Habsburg privateers from Dunkirk (while Spanish Netherlands) terrorized English and Dutch shipping. Jean Bart later operated from here for France.

havens.name: Providence Island (Isla de Providencia), Colombia
havens.description: English Puritan colony established 1630. Quickly turned to privateering against Spanish. Captured by Spain 1641.

havens.name: Charles Town (Charleston), South Carolina
havens.description: NOT a haven - Blackbeard BLOCKADED Charleston harbor May 1718, holding prominent citizens hostage for medical supplies. Showed pirate audacity at its peak.

havens.name: Trist Island / Île-à-Vache, Haiti
havens.description: Buccaneer meeting point and staging area south of Hispaniola. Henry Morgan assembled his fleet here for the Panama raid 1670.
havens.features: Sheltered anchorage, proximity to Spanish shipping lanes

havens.name: Roatán, Bay Islands, Honduras
havens.description: English buccaneers and logwood cutters used these islands as a base. Spanish repeatedly tried to dislodge them. Strategic position in western Caribbean.
notable_pirates: English logwood cutters who turned pirate
havens.features: Excellent harbor, fresh water, proximity to Spanish Honduras
havens.current_status: Honduran island, major cruise ship destination.

havens.name: Antongil Bay, Madagascar
havens.description: Large protected bay on northeast Madagascar. Used as pirate anchorage and trading post. Multiple pirate settlements.

havens.name: Perim Island, Bab-el-Mandeb Strait
havens.description: Strategic chokepoint at mouth of Red Sea. Pirates waited here to intercept Mughal pilgrim ships and Indian Ocean traders. Henry Every's fateful attack on Mughal fleet was near here.
havens.features: Strategic chokepoint, all Red Sea traffic passes

wrecks.name: San Esteban

location.location_notes: Precise wreck site known from archaeological excavation

wrecks.cargo: 85,000+ lbs silver coins & bars from Mexican mint - worth $10M (1975)
wrecks.cargo_detail: Silver bars, silver coins (pesos), cochineal, hides
wrecks.notes: Part of 1554 fleet disaster. 'Wreck of the Three Hundred'. Survivors killed by Karankawa. Only 41% salvaged in 1554. World's oldest dated mariner's astrolabe recovered.

wrecks.name: Espíritu Santo

location.location_notes: Excavated site, precise location known

wrecks.notes: Sister ship to San Esteban. Found 1964. Gold bar, jewelry, navigation equipment recovered by Platoro Ltd. Texas Antiquities Code passed because of this wreck.

wrecks.name: Santa María de Yciar

location.location_notes: Destroyed by dredgers - original site approximate

wrecks.notes: Third ship of 1554 fleet. Hull split, cargo scattered. Accidentally destroyed by dredgers in late 1950s.

wrecks.name: La Girona

location.description: Lacada Point, County Antrim, Northern Ireland
location.location_notes: Precise location known, debris field mapped

wrecks.cargo: Gold coins, silver, jewelry, gold cross of Knight of Malta
wrecks.cargo_detail: Treasure from three Armada ships combined aboard. Gold ducats, chains, rings, religious items.
wrecks.notes: Spanish Armada galleass. Only 9 survivors from 1,300. Treasure recovered 1967-68 by Robert Sténuit. Ulster Museum Belfast exhibits. Carried treasure and refugees from wrecked Armada ships.

route.position_in_voyage: Retreating around British Isles after Armada defeat

sources.title: Priceless Relics of the Spanish Armada
sources.author: Robert Sténuit

wrecks.name: Santa María de la Rosa

location.location_notes: Located by Sydney Wignall 1968

wrecks.cause: Storm during Armada retreat, anchors dragged
wrecks.cargo: Pay chests, personal valuables of soldiers and nobility
wrecks.cargo_detail: Silver coins, pewter, weapons, personal effects
wrecks.notes: Vice-flagship of Guipuzcoan Squadron. Only one survivor - son of the pilot. Discovered by Sydney Wignall in 1968. First Spanish Armada ship to be archaeologically excavated.

wrecks.name: Trinidad Valencera

location.location_notes: Located 1971, excavated by City of Derry Sub-Aqua Club

wrecks.cause: Beached after storm damage during Armada retreat
wrecks.cargo_detail: Bronze cannons, silver coins, weapons, ceramics
wrecks.notes: 1,100-ton Venetian grain ship requisitioned by Spain. Carried 42 guns including four massive 50-pounder siege guns. Most of 450 men surrendered to Irish; some executed by English.

sources.title: Full Fathom Five: Wrecks of the Spanish Armada
sources.author: Colin Martin

wrecks.name: Flor de la Mar

location.description: Strait of Malacca, off coast of Sumatra - NEVER FOUND
location.location_notes: NEVER FOUND. Lost near Timia Point in Kingdom of Aru, Sumatra. Exact position unknown.

wrecks.cargo: Treasure of Malacca Sultan - estimated $2.6 BILLION. Gold throne, 60 tons of gold, giant bronze lions, crown jewels, gems.
wrecks.cargo_detail: Gold from conquest of Malacca, tribute from Siam (crown, sword, ruby ring), personal treasure of Afonso de Albuquerque
wrecks.notes: NEVER FOUND! Called 'richest wreck in history'. Afonso de Albuquerque survived on improvised raft. Portugal, Malaysia, and Indonesia all claim salvage rights. 400-ton carrack, largest of its time.

route.position_in_voyage: Returning from Malacca conquest with treasure

waypoints.name: Lisbon, Portugal (Built)
waypoints.notes: Built in Lisbon shipyards. 400 tons - largest carrack yet built, nearly twice size of previous India Run ships.

waypoints.name: Maiden Voyage to India
waypoints.notes: First voyage under Estevão da Gama (cousin of Vasco da Gama). Part of 4th Portuguese India Armada.

waypoints.name: Mozambique Channel (Repairs)
waypoints.notes: Ship proved unwieldy when loaded. Sprung leaks, forced to stop at Mozambique Island for 2 months of repairs.

waypoints.name: India Run 1505
waypoints.notes: Second voyage under João da Nova with 7th India Armada (22 ships). Carried first Viceroy Francisco de Almeida.

waypoints.name: Stuck in Mozambique
waypoints.notes: Again ran into difficulties in Mozambique Channel. Stuck for 10 months.

waypoints.name: Conquest of Socotra
waypoints.notes: Participated under Tristão da Cunha's command

waypoints.name: Conquest of Muscat/Ormuz
waypoints.notes: Under Afonso de Albuquerque. Conquered Curiati, Muscat, Khor Fakkan, Ormuz.

waypoints.name: Battle of Diu
waypoints.notes: Served as flagship of Viceroy Francisco de Almeida

waypoints.name: Conquest of Goa
waypoints.notes: Supported Albuquerque's conquest

waypoints.name: Conquest of Malacca
waypoints.notes: Supported capture of Malacca. Albuquerque loaded Sultan's treasure for transport to Portugal.

waypoints.name: Wreck Site - Strait of Malacca
waypoints.notes: NEVER FOUND. Storm caught ship off northeast Sumatra. Wrecked on shoals near Timia Point, Kingdom of Aru. Albuquerque survived on improvised raft. 400+ men lost.

route.service_years: 1502-1511 (9 years - remarkably long for India Run ships)
route.historical_significance: Prototype for typical 16th-century India nau. Experience led to 'outer route' east of Madagascar for heavy ships.
route_sources: João de Barros - Décadas da Ásia (1552)

sources.title: The Commentaries of the Great Afonso Dalboquerque
sources.author: Afonso de Albuquerque (trans. W. Birch)

wrecks.name: Nuestra Señora de Atocha

location.location_notes: Precisely located, debris trail extends 9 miles

wrecks.cargo_detail: Gold bars, silver bars, silver coins, emeralds, indigo, tobacco, copper
wrecks.notes: Famous treasure recovered by Mel Fisher 1985 after 16 years searching. 'Today's the Day' every morning. Sterncastle still missing. Museum in Key West. $450 million recovered.

route.position_in_voyage: Florida Straits after Havana departure - guard ship at rear of fleet

wrecks.name: Santa Margarita

location.location_notes: Precisely located by Mel Fisher

wrecks.notes: Sister ship to Atocha. Recovered by Mel Fisher 1980.

wrecks.name: Nuestra Señora del Rosario

location.location_notes: General area known, not fully excavated

wrecks.cargo: Silver bars, silver coins, trade goods
wrecks.cargo_detail: Part of 1622 Tierra Firme fleet
wrecks.notes: Almiranta (vice-flagship) of 1622 fleet. Ran aground on Dry Tortugas. Salvaged by Spanish soon after loss. Possible remaining treasure not recovered.

route.position_in_voyage: Florida Straits after Havana departure - Almiranta (vice-flagship)

wrecks.name: Nuestra Señora del Juncal

location.description: Gulf of Mexico, between Campeche and Veracruz - NEVER FOUND
location.location_notes: NEVER FOUND. Historical records suggest sinking in hurricane between Campeche Bank and Veracruz. Search area spans 100+ nautical miles.

wrecks.cargo: 3.6 MILLION PESOS in silver/gold + 135,000 lbs cochineal + Chinese silk
wrecks.cargo_detail: Silver bars, silver coins (8 reales), gold, cochineal dye, Chinese silk, porcelain
wrecks.notes: NEVER FOUND! Flagship of 1631 New Spain fleet. Most valuable unfound Spanish treasure ship after San José. Spain & Mexico jointly searching. Contemporary accounts place loss ~50 leagues from Veracruz.

route.position_in_voyage: En route to Havana, struck by hurricane in Gulf of Mexico - Capitana (flagship)

waypoints.name: Veracruz, Mexico
waypoints.notes: Departed as flagship of 1631 New Spain Fleet (19 ships). Fleet exceptionally laden - first sailing since 1628 when Dutch captured entire fleet at Battle of Matanzas.

waypoints.name: Gulf of Mexico (Storm Area)
waypoints.notes: Tropical cyclone struck fleet approximately one week after departure. No vessel emerged intact.

waypoints.name: Wreck Site (Approximate)
waypoints.notes: NEVER FOUND. Sank 8 leagues north of 'Bajo de las Áreas' (location unknown). Only 35-39 of 335 aboard survived in small boat.

route.cargo_documented: 3,644,198 pesos silver/gold, 135,200 lbs cochineal, 385,325 lbs indigo, 10,018 lbs Chinese silk
route_sources: Robert F. Marx - Shipwrecks in the Americas (1983)
Timothy R. Walton - The Spanish Treasure Fleets (1994)

wrecks.name: Nuestra Señora de la Concepción

location.description: Silver Shoals, north of Dominican Republic
location.location_notes: General area known, debris scattered across reef system

wrecks.cargo_detail: Silver bars and coins from Peru via Panama
wrecks.notes: William Phips salvaged 1687 for English Crown - made him a knight and launched his political career. Silver Shoals named for this wreck. Peruvian silver route via Callao.

route.origin: Portobelo (Peruvian silver via Panama) via Havana
route.position_in_voyage: North of Hispaniola, blown off course by hurricane

waypoints.name: Potosí, Bolivia (Silver Origin)
waypoints.notes: Silver mined at Cerro Rico ('Rich Hill')

waypoints.name: Callao, Peru
waypoints.notes: Silver consolidated at port of Lima, loaded onto Pacific fleet

waypoints.name: Panama City, Panama
waypoints.notes: Silver unloaded from Pacific ships, crossed isthmus by mule train

waypoints.name: Portobelo, Panama
waypoints.notes: Silver loaded onto Tierra Firme fleet ships including Concepción

waypoints.name: Havana, Cuba
waypoints.notes: Fleet consolidated for Atlantic crossing

waypoints.name: Wreck Site - Silver Shoals
waypoints.notes: Hurricane blew ship north of intended course. Ran aground on reef north of Dominican Republic. ~200 casualties.

route.salvage_history: William Phips salvaged 1687 for English Crown - made him a knight, launched political career. Site gave 'Silver Shoals' its name.

wrecks.name: Nuestra Señora de las Maravillas

location.location_notes: Primary site known, debris field extends several km

wrecks.cause: Collision with flagship Capitana in night
wrecks.cargo: Gold, silver, emeralds - 3.5 million items recovered over centuries
wrecks.cargo_detail: Massive treasure from Peru and Mexico
wrecks.notes: One of richest wrecks ever. Allen Exploration ongoing since 2020. Treasure recovered 1650s-1990s. Bahamas Maritime Museum exhibits. New discoveries still being made.

route.origin: Havana (after consolidating New Spain and Tierra Firme treasure)
route.position_in_voyage: Bahama Channel, collided with Capitana at night

wrecks.name: Nuestra Señora de Encarnación

location.location_notes: Discovered 2011, precisely mapped

wrecks.cargo_detail: Swords, nails, cloth, horseshoes, ceramics, Peruvian silver
wrecks.notes: Discovered 2011 by Texas State University. Remarkably intact. Part of Tierra Firme fleet carrying Peruvian treasure. Built in Veracruz.

route.position_in_voyage: At Portobelo/Chagres area, wrecked before departure

sources.title: Discovery of the Spanish Merchant Vessel Nuestra Señora de Encarnación
sources.author: Fritz Hanselmann et al.

wrecks.name: Nuestra Señora de la Soledad

location.description: Punta de Brujas, near Chagres River, Panama - NOT LOCATED
location.location_notes: Approximate location based on historical accounts, exact site not confirmed

wrecks.cause: Storm - struck rocks and broke apart
wrecks.notes: Same Tierra Firme fleet as Encarnación. Captain Antonio de Lima drowned. All treasure lost. Exact wreck site not definitively located.

route.position_in_voyage: At Portobelo/Chagres area, wrecked before departure

wrecks.name: Henrietta Marie

location.description: New Ground Reef, 35 miles west of Key West, Florida
location.location_notes: Precisely located, excavated

wrecks.cause: Unknown - wrecked on reef returning to England
wrecks.cargo: Trade goods, sugar, cotton, dyewoods, ginger
wrecks.cargo_detail: Iron bilboes (slave shackles), trade goods, glass beads, ship's bell dated 1699
wrecks.notes: Only identified slave ship wreck in US waters. Found 1972 by Mel Fisher's team during Atocha search. Memorial plaque placed by National Association of Black Scuba Divers 1993.

route.position_in_voyage: Return leg (Leg 3) - Jamaica to England via Florida Straits

sources.title: The Wreck of the Henrietta Marie
sources.author: Michael H. Cottman

wrecks.name: San José

location.location_notes: Colombian government classified exact location

wrecks.notes: Holy Grail of shipwrecks. Located 2015 by Woods Hole. First artifacts recovered 2024-2025. Legal disputes between Colombia, Spain, and salvage companies.

wrecks.name: RMS Titanic
wrecks.notes: Most famous shipwreck in history. Located 1985 by Robert Ballard.

wrecks.name: SS Central America
wrecks.cargo: 21 tons California Gold Rush gold, coins
wrecks.notes: Ship of Gold. Over $100M recovered. Tommy Thompson found it 1988, later jailed for contempt.

wrecks.name: Whydah Gally
wrecks.cargo: Plunder from 50+ captured ships - gold, silver, African trade goods
wrecks.cargo_detail: 4.5-5 tons gold/silver, gold dust, jewelry divided into 180 x 50-lb sacks
wrecks.notes: Only authenticated Golden Age pirate shipwreck ever found. Captain 'Black Sam' Bellamy. Found by Barry Clifford 1984. Ship's bell (1985) and brass placard (2013) proved identity.

route.original_purpose: Slave ship completing maiden triangle trade voyage

waypoints.name: London, England (Built)
waypoints.notes: Commissioned by Sir Humphrey Morice, MP and slave merchant. 300-ton galley ship, 110 ft.

waypoints.name: West African Coast (Slave Trading)
waypoints.notes: Sailed down West African coast through Gambia, Senegal, to Nigeria and Benin. Named after Kingdom of Whydah slave port (modern Ouidah). Loaded ~500 enslaved people, Akan gold jewelry, ivory.

waypoints.name: Jamaica, Caribbean
waypoints.notes: Traded/sold enslaved people and cargo for precious metals, sugar, indigo, rum.

waypoints.name: Windward Passage (Pirate Attack)
waypoints.notes: Captured by pirate Samuel Bellamy commanding Sultana (26 guns) and Marianne (10 guns). Three-day chase.

waypoints.name: Near Bahamas (Capture)
waypoints.notes: Captain Lawrence Prince surrendered. Bellamy gave him Sultana plus £20 in silver/gold.

waypoints.name: Blanco Islet, BVI (Pirate Base)
waypoints.notes: Bellamy's home port, later renamed Bellamy Cay. Ship refitted with 10 additional cannons (28 total). Ship razeed for speed.

waypoints.name: Carolina Coast (Raiding)
waypoints.notes: Sailed north along American coast, capturing ships. Storm damaged ship, broke mast.

waypoints.name: Block Island/Rhode Island (Repairs)
waypoints.notes: Repairs effected. Additional 30+ cannons added below decks as ballast.

waypoints.name: Near Cape Cod (Mary Anne Capture)
waypoints.notes: Captured ship Mary Anne laden with Madeira wine. Around sunset, winds died, massive fog rolled in.

waypoints.name: Wreck Site - Wellfleet, Massachusetts
waypoints.notes: Violent nor'easter with 70 mph winds, 30-40 ft waves. Midnight: hit sandbar 500 ft from shore. Main mast snapped, ship capsized. Only 2 of 146 aboard survived.

route_sources: Colin Woodard - The Republic of Pirates (2007)

wrecks.name: 1715 Fleet - Capitana (Nuestra Señora de la Regla)

location.description: Treasure Coast, Florida (Fort Pierce to Sebastian)
location.location_notes: 11 ships scattered along 50+ miles of coast

wrecks.cargo: Estimated $400 million in gold/silver/jewels. Mexican and Peruvian silver, Chinese porcelain from Manila trade, 'Queens Jewels' (gold ornaments for Queen of Spain)
wrecks.notes: 11 ships lost, 12th (French frigate Le Grifon) survived by staying further out to sea. Kip Wagner found first treasure 1961. Still actively salvaged - coins wash up on beaches after storms. 2015: $4.5M gold chain found. 2025: $1M in coins recovered.

route.type: Combined Fleet Return (New Spain + Tierra Firme)
route.fleet_commanders: Captain-General Don Juan Esteban de Ubilla (New Spain Fleet), Don Antonio de Echeverz y Zubiza (Tierra Firme Fleet)

waypoints.name: Veracruz, Mexico (New Spain Fleet origin)
waypoints.notes: New Spain Fleet (Flota) collected Mexican silver and Manila Galleon goods

waypoints.name: Portobelo, Panama (Tierra Firme origin)
waypoints.notes: Tierra Firme Fleet collected Peruvian silver (Potosí)

waypoints.name: Havana, Cuba (Fleet Consolidation)
waypoints.notes: New Spain and Tierra Firme fleets merged. 11 Spanish ships + French frigate Le Grifon. Departed for Spain.

waypoints.name: Florida Straits (Hurricane)
waypoints.notes: Hurricane struck 7 days after departing Havana. All 11 Spanish ships lost.

location.description: Off Chanduy, Ecuador (near Peru border) - DISCOVERED
location.location_notes: Lost after striking reef off Chanduy, Ecuador. Near Peru-Panama treasure route.

wrecks.cargo: Peruvian silver, gold, precious stones - massive treasure from Potosí via Callao
wrecks.cargo_detail: Spanish colonial treasure from Peru bound for Panama crossing
wrecks.notes: Spanish treasure ship (Capitana/flagship) wrecked off Ecuador coast near Peru. Part of the Peru-Panama treasure route carrying silver from Potosí mines. Also known simply as 'Capitana'. One of few colonial wrecks found near Peru/Ecuador coast.

route.position_in_voyage: Off Ecuador coast, en route to Panama

sources.title: List of shipwrecks of South America

wrecks.cause: Run against reef by pursuing pirates
wrecks.cargo: Gold, silver, precious gems - treasure from Peru
wrecks.cargo_detail: Laden with gold, silver, and precious gems from Peru
wrecks.notes: Spanish treasure ship run against a reef by pursuing pirates off Ecuador coast. Discovered in 1998. Carried treasure from Peru. Part of the Peru-Panama silver route.

sources.title: List of shipwrecks of South America

wrecks.name: 1746 Callao Harbor Fleet (Earthquake/Tsunami Wrecks)

location.description: Callao Harbor, Peru - DESTROYED BY TSUNAMI
location.location_notes: All 23 vessels in Callao harbor destroyed by 24-meter tsunami. Some thrown nearly a mile inland. Buried under rubble/sediment.

wrecks.cargo: Silver worth 300 million piasters according to contemporary accounts. Ships carried silver from Potosí mines.
wrecks.cargo_detail: Warships Fermín and San Antonio thrown inland. 24 vessels reportedly carried silver worth 300 million piasters.
wrecks.notes: MAJOR DISASTER - NEVER FULLY RECOVERED. Largest earthquake in central Peru history. Tsunami (24m/80ft) destroyed all 23 vessels in Callao harbor plus the port city. Only ~200 of 5,000 Callao residents survived. Warships Fermín and San Antonio were thrown nearly a mile inland. Contemporary accounts (Khlebnikov 1817) reported '24 vessels which carried silver worth 300 million piasters' lost. Ships likely buried under debris and sediment. Port of Lima - main exit point for Peruvian silver from Potosí. Potential treasure site.

sources.title: 1746 Lima-Callao earthquake
sources.note: M8.6-8.8 earthquake and 24m tsunami destroyed Callao and all 23 vessels in harbor

sources.title: Memoirs of Kiril Khlebnikov (1817)
sources.note: Russian-American Company employee who visited Callao 70 years after disaster, described seeing ruins and reported '24 vessels which carried silver worth 300 million piasters'

wrecks.name: San Miguel Arcángel (UNCONFIRMED - Research Lead)

location.description: Possibly off Peru coast - UNCONFIRMED/NOT LOCATED
location.location_notes: UNCONFIRMED. Research lead - ship name 'San Miguel Arcángel' (Archangel Saint Michael) was common for Spanish colonial vessels. No specific wreck with this exact name confirmed off Peru in available records.

wrecks.cargo: Unknown - possibly treasure from Potosí route
wrecks.notes: RESEARCH LEAD - NOT CONFIRMED. User query mentioned 'Michael Angel' or similar ship name, possibly 1700s, lost near Peru. 'San Miguel Arcángel' (Archangel Saint Michael) was a common Spanish ship name. No specific wreck with this exact name found in Wikipedia, wrecksite.eu, or other public databases for Peru coast. POSSIBLE CANDIDATES: 1) San Miguel (+1542) mentioned in 16th century list but likely Azores not Peru. 2) Ships lost in 1746 Callao disaster may include vessels with this name. 3) May be confused with 'Jesus Maria de la Limpia Concepcion' (1654) or 'Santa Maria de la Consolacion' (1681) off Ecuador/Peru. RECOMMENDATION: Check Archivo General de Indias (Seville) for fleet manifests on Peru-Panama route. Search for 'San Miguel', 'Arcángel', 'Miguel Ángel' variants in Spanish maritime records.

searched_sources: Wikipedia - List of shipwrecks of South America

Santa Maria de la Consolacion (1681) - off Ecuador/Peru

San Miguel (+1542) - 16th century but likely Azores
